Experiments with hyphens

This paragraph is dddddd Maximalwert Maximalwert wunderschön Maximalwert Maximalwert Maximalwert Maximalwert Maximalwert using the the lang attribute on its container, and the hyphens: auto property, For example, if you are designing a brand new website for someone, most times you will have to make sure the prototype looks finished by inserting text or photos or what have you. The purpose of this is so the person viewing the prototype has a chance to actually feel and understand the idea behind what you have created.

You can also put the lang attribute on other elements, like this paragraph, and then add inline css, if you want to limit the hyphenation effect.

BUT not all browsers support the hyphens: auto property! See CanIUse.com.

However, even without the lang attribute, or the hyphens: auto property, you can add soft hyphens like I've done in these words, and the browser will use that if needed: super­cali­fragi­listic­espeali­docious super­cali­fragi­listic­espeali­docious super­cali­fragi­listic­espeali­docious super­cali­fragi­listic­espeali­docious.

Finally, note that the hard hyphen can come in handy sometimes to get the browser to use it as an optional line‐break, while keeping the hyphen visible even if the line doesn't break. For ex: line‐break‐a‐pottamus, line‐break‐0‐rama, line‐a‐line‐a‐ding‐dong‐break‐it‐where‐ever‐louie!

In contrast, not all browsers will break those words without the hard hyphen in the HTML. For ex: line-break-a-pottamus, line-break-O-rama, line-a-line-a-ding-dong-break-it-where-ever-louie!

‐ (unicode U+2010)

This represents a “hard hyphen.” A hyphen will be presented whether or not there is a line break.

­ (unicode U+00AD)

This represents a “soft hyphen.” A hyphen will only be presented when the line actually breaks. Otherwise, the word will not be hyphenated at that position.

From this article on WebDesignerDepot.

See also CSS-Tricks on Hyphens.
